intro: Quercus lobata subsp. walteri, commonly known as the valley oak, is a subspecies of the coast live oak native to California. It is a large evergreen tree that can grow up to 30 meters tall, characterized by its broad, lobed leaves and a rounded crown. The leaves are typically 5–12 cm long and have a leathery texture with prominent veins. It produces small, acorn-like fruits that are an important food source for various wildlife species. The tree thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in riparian and valley habitats.
